bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Joseph B. Brown, September 2, 1874

div1.p: Reed accepts an invitation to appear before the U.S. Surgeon's Examining Board, and explains that he would have responded sooner had he not contracted a fever. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Joseph B. Brown, September 2, 1874
div1.p:
Sta. Chq.
Walter Reed to
see S.G.O.
6475 P.

Reports, and enquires
it what time to pre-
sent himself for
examination

Notice mailed Sept. 2, 1874
Presence required Janry
18, 1875

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Joseph B. Brown, September 2, 1874
div1.opener:
115 Lee Ave.
Brooklyn,
Septr 2nd, 74,
Surgeon Jos. B. Brown,
Pres. Examining Board U.S.A.
Sir:
div1.p:
On Monday
Aug. 31st, I received from
Asst. Surgeon General C. H. Crane
an invitation to appear before
the Army Examining Board for
Examination, and, also, was
requested to report the
same to you, by letter. I
would have reported
to you, without delay, had
I not been deterred from
so doing by an attack of
Intermittent fever, from
which I have not yet entirely
recovered.

To-day, I am in receipt
of a letter from the Recorder
of the Board, Dr. A. H. Hoff,
notifying me to appear be-
fore the Board for Exam-
ination on the 18th day of
January 1875. I shall, ac-
cordingly, hold myself in
readiness to appear at said
date.

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be,
Your obt. Servant,
